nexttext:
One of the nice features of deformed $\mathcal{N}=4$ SYM is that at one loop, the beta function of the gauge coupling vanishes, and the beta functions of Yukawa couplings do not depend on the quartic scalar couplings. So as the first step one can search for fixed points of Yukawa couplings without worrying about the quartic scalar couplings. In the second step one searches for fixed points of quartic scalar couplings with Yukawa couplings fixed.

Actually we found the amplitude also vanishes at one loop if $T_{ABCD}=0$, and it is natural to expect it to vanish at all loops in conformal deformations of $\mathcal{N}=4$ SYM.


\section{Classification of Protected Operators}
\label{section4}

From the last section we see that the Leigh-Strassler deformation lies in the global minima of Yukawa renormalization potential $\rho$. However, it is possible that there are other (non-supersymmetric) conformal fixed points in the neighborhood of the Leigh-Strassler deformation, then the renormalization group flow may end up reaching these non-supersymmetric conformal fixed points, and supersymmetry fails to emerge. To exclude this possibility we shall develop a method to determine the number of physical parameters of the space formed by all conformal fixed points.

The space of 'all conformal deformations' may have multiple components, and in different components, the space may have different dimensions. So to be more accurate we define the term 'sector':  the sector of a given conformal fixed point is the irreducible component containing a neighborhood of the point in the space of conformal deformations. The Leigh-Strassler deformation has 4 real physical parameters (More details can be found in Section \ref{section5}), so locally it is the only fixed line if the enclosing sector also has 4 physical parameters.

Different fixed points in the same sector are physically equivalent if they are related by $SO(6)$ and $U(4)$ redefinitions of scalars and fermions. So number of 'physical' parameters is the dimension of the quotient space of the sector by $SO(6)\times U(4)$.

nexttext:
The number of $\mathcal{O}_a$ is $N_p$, and the number of $\mathcal{O}_i$ is at most 31. But it is possible that a subgroup of $U(4)\times SO(6)$, $G_{sym}$, is preserved in the theory. In this case, the corresponding $\mathcal{O}_i$ vanishes, so the number of $\mathcal{O}_i$ is the same as the number of generators of the quotient group $U(4)\times SO(6)/G_{sym}$. For example, $\mathcal{N}=4$ SYM has a $SU(4)$ symmetry, so the number of $\mathcal{O}_i$ is only 16. $\gamma_i$ deformed SYM has a $U(1)^3$ symmetry, and the number of $\mathcal{O}_i$ is 28.

The last type of protected operators, $\mathcal{O}_{\alpha}$, have non-vanishing beta functions but the first order beta function vanishes 'accidentally',

nexttext:
The condition under which the theory is conformal up to three loops (four loops in planar limit) was given in \cite{Bork:2007bj}.

The Leigh-Strassler deformation has 46 protected Yukawa operators \footnote{The anomalous dimensions of quartic scalar operators will be modified when these protected Yukawa operators are added to the Lagrangian. So strictly speaking, protected Yukawa operators should also contain a quartic scalar piece.}. 30 protected operators correspond to the variation of the Lagrangian under SO(6) and U(4) rotations of scalars and fermions. 4 protected operators corresponds to the variation of the Lagrangian when the parameter of the theory, $\beta$ and $h$ change. The left 12 operators are accidentally protected operators\footnote{In \eqref{accidental} $O_1^i$ and $O_2^i$ are both complex operators and only contain chiral fermions. Each of them corresponds to 2 real accidentally protected operator which contain both chiral and anti-chiral fermions.}:

From \eqref{npex}, the number of parameters in the enclosing sector is $N_p=4$, so we have proved that as far as Yukawa couplings are concerned, locally the Leigh-Strassler deformation is the only conformal deformation.



Next we study the renormalization group flow of quartic scalar couplings.  Quartic scalar couplings also has a renormalization potential $V_S$,

nexttext:
$V_S$ is a polynomial of degree 3 in $a_{IJKL}$ so it does not have a global minimum. Nevertheless, $V_S$ may have local minima or saddle points, corresponding to stable or unstable fixed points of single trace scalar couplings, respectively. For the Leigh-Strassler theory, $V_S^{LS}=0$.

Anomalous dimension matrix of $a_{IJKL}$ is still positive semi-definite. There are 6 protected scalar operators, and they are combinations of three holomorphic and three anti-holomorphic operators.

nexttext: We can expand $V_S$ as the power of $z_i$ and $\bar{z}_i$. The $\mathcal{O}(z)$ order vanishes because it is  proportional to beta functions in Leigh-Strassler theory.
